metadata.case_name: Sawai Singhai Nirmal Chand v. Union of India

facts.text: Phool Chand, predecessor-in-title of appellant Sawai Singhai Nirmal Chand, instituted suit against respondent Union of India in Court of Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, and obtained decree on 25-4-1951 for Rs. 24,234-14-0 and proportionate costs with interest at 4% per annum.
Respondent challenged decree by appeal in High Court; pending appeal, deposited decretal amount of Rs. 31,849-9-9.
On 14-12-1952, Phool Chand withdrew Rs. 28,032-12-0 out of deposited amount after furnishing security.
Respondent's appeal partly allowed on 26-6-1954; decretal amount reduced to Rs. 10,971-15-6, resulting in excess withdrawal by Phool Chand of Rs. 15,340-14-8.
On 4-9-1954, respondent applied for restitution of excess amount Rs. 15,340-14-8 with interest.
Second Additional District Judge allowed restitution application; in execution, sought attachment and sale of Phool Chand's immovable properties.
Properties sold by Phool Chand to appellant by registered sale deed on 9-1-1953.
Appellant objected to attachment under O.21 r.58; objection overruled and application dismissed by Second Additional District Judge on 16-4-1957.
Appellant gave notice to respondent under s.80 CPC on 12-4-1958.
Appellant filed suit under O.21 r.63 on 23-6-1958 in Court of First Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, claiming declaration of title via sale deed and injunction against attachment/sale.
Respondent raised plea of limitation; common ground that limitation under Art.11 Limitation Act is one year from order under O.21 r.58.
If s.80 applies, suit within time; if not, barred by time.
Trial Judge and Madhya Pradesh High Court held s.80 inapplicable; suit dismissed as barred by time on 14-3-1961 in First Appeal No.57 of 1959.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether a suit filed in pursuance of O.21 r.63 of the Code of Civil Procedure attracts the provisions of s.80 of the Code.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit under O.21 r.63 is a suit against Government (Union of India), so s.80 applies; notice period excludable, suit within limitation.

respondent_arguments.text: s.80 does not apply to suit under O.21 r.63; it is continuation of attachment proceedings or form of appeal; notice period not excludable, suit barred by limitation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: O.21 r.58,63 CPC; Phul Kumari v. Ghanshyam Misra (Privy Council)

respondent_arguments.text: No need for s.80 notice as Government already aware of claim from prior proceedings; purpose of s.80 absent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Amar Nath Dogra v. Union of India

court_reasoning.text: Suit under O.21 r.63 is a regular suit against Government, commenced by plaint; s.80 words are wide, express, explicit, mandatory; no exceptions permissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceedings under O.21 r.63 are a suit; order under r.58 conclusive subject to such suit.

court_reasoning.text: Suit not mere continuation of attachment proceedings; scope wider (title, not just possession); Phul Kumari distinguished as limited to court-fees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: r.58 enquiry limited to possession; r.63 suit concerns title.

court_reasoning.text: Purpose of s.80 (settle claims, avoid litigation) irrelevant; plain words govern; rare for Government to deny notice need.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.80 admits no implications or exceptions per Bhagchand Dagadusa.

holdings.text: s.80 CPC applies to suit under O.21 r.63 against Government.

precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with court-fees for suit under predecessor to O.21 r.63; not authority that such suit is continuation/appeal for all purposes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amar Nath Dogra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Notice before first suit satisfies s.80 for second on same cause; affirms notice necessity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagchand Dagadusa v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: s.80 applies to all suits including injunctions; express, explicit, mandatory; no exceptions.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs objection to attachment, suit to establish right, mandatory notice to Government.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: One year limitation for suit under O.21 r.63 from date of order.

statutes_cited.name: Court Fees Act, 1870
statutes_cited.relevance: Context in Phul Kumari for court-fees on suits to set aside summary orders.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds s.80 applies to suit under O.21 r.63; reverses High Court and trial court decisions dismissing suit as time-barred.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; suit held within time.

key_quotes.text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether a suit filed in pursuance of O. 21 r. 63 of the Code of Civil Procedure attracts the provisions of s.80 of the Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The material words used in s. 80 are wide and unambiguous they are express, explicit and mandatory, and it would be difficult to except from their operation any proceeding which can be regarded as a suit against the Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 80 is express, explicit and mandatory, and it admits of no implications or exceptions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Privy Council to reject exceptions to s.80.
